skill.name: Clean Code Reviewer
skill.description: Analyze code quality based on Clean Code principles. Identify naming, function size, duplication, over-engineering, and magic number issues with severity ratings and refactoring suggestions.
skill.summary: Code quality analysis based on Clean Code principles
skill.author: hylarucoder

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing code review guidelines and educational examples. Static scanner flagged markdown code block delimiters as command execution patterns and HTTP status constants as cryptographic algorithms. All findings are false positives - the skill contains no executable code, network calls, or system access capability.

content.user_title: Review Code for Clean Code Principles
content.value_statement: Poor code quality slows down teams and introduces bugs. This skill analyzes code against Clean Code principles to identify naming issues, function problems, duplication, over-engineering, and magic numbers with actionable refactoring suggestions.
actual_capabilities: Analyzes code against 7 Clean Code dimensions: naming, functions, DRY, YAGNI, magic numbers, clarity, and project conventions
Identifies poor naming patterns like data1, temp, info and suggests meaningful alternatives
Detects functions exceeding 100 lines or with more than 3 parameters
Flags duplicate logic, dead code, over-engineering patterns, and hardcoded values
Rates issues by severity (high, medium, low) with prioritized refactoring suggestions
Supports TypeScript, Python, and Go with language-specific patterns
limitations: Does not modify code automatically - provides recommendations only
Does not execute or test code behavior
Does not analyze performance or security issues
Requires user to review and apply suggestions manually

use_cases.title: Daily Code Review
use_cases.description: Get instant feedback on code quality during development to maintain consistent standards.

use_cases.title: Team Code Standards
use_cases.description: Enforce Clean Code principles across the team with automated quality checks.

use_cases.title: Legacy Code Improvements
use_cases.description: Identify specific issues to address when modernizing existing codebases.

prompt_templates.title: Quick Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this code for Clean Code violations and suggest improvements.

prompt_templates.title: Component Check
prompt_templates.prompt: Review all components in /src/components for naming, function size, and duplication issues.

prompt_templates.title: Language Focus
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this Python file for type hints, mutable defaults, and list comprehension issues.

prompt_templates.title: Full Audit
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform a complete Clean Code audit across the entire codebase, categorize issues by severity, and provide a prioritized refactoring plan.

output_examples.input: Review this function for Clean Code issues
output: - Line 12: `const d = new Date()` - Use meaningful names like `currentDate`
- Line 15: `const data1` - Replace generic names with specific purpose like `userList`
- Line 34: Function exceeds 100 lines - Consider splitting into smaller functions
- Line 45: Hardcoded `86400000` - Extract to named constant `ONE_DAY_MS`

best_practices: Apply high-severity issues first as they impact maintainability most
Use the severity levels to prioritize refactoring efforts across iterations
Cross-reference findings with your project AGENTS.md or CLAUDE.md conventions
anti_patterns: Ignoring low consistently-severity issues allows technical debt to accumulate
Making functional changes while refactoring - keep refactoring focused on code quality only
Applying suggestions without understanding the reasoning behind each recommendation

faq.question: What languages does this skill support?
faq.answer: TypeScript, Python, and Go with language-specific anti-patterns and examples.

faq.question: Does this skill modify my code?
faq.answer: No, it only analyzes and provides recommendations. You apply changes manually.

faq.question: How are severity levels determined?
faq.answer: High impacts maintainability and should be fixed immediately. Medium has improvement space. Low is optional code smell.

faq.question: Can I scope reviews to specific directories?
faq.answer: Yes, specify the scope in your prompt like /clean-code-reviewer --scope=components.

faq.question: Does this check for security issues?
faq.answer: No, this focuses on code quality patterns like naming and structure, not security vulnerabilities.

faq.question: How detailed are the suggestions?
faq.answer: Suggestions include the principle violated, file location, severity, and a refactoring direction.
